EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





This document comprises the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Kemira Water Solutions, Inc. facility located at 18700 Highway 14 North in Mojave, California 93501 (also referred to as the Mojave Plant).  The facility is located in an undeveloped area approximately 1.5 miles northeast of the town of Mojave.  The Mojave Airport, which is the nearest neighboring facility, is approximately 1 mile away. 



The purpose of this document is to comply with various risk management planning requirements.  These are set forth in Section 25535(d) of Article 2 of Chapter 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code (also known as the California Accidental Release Prevention Program - CalARP) and Part 68 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40CFR Part 68).  The latter is also known as the federal Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs or the federal RMP.  



The scope of the RMP includes all operations conducted at Kemira Water Solutions, Inc. Mojave facility which involve the storage, handling and/or use of chlorine.   Chlorine is the only regulated substance which is handled at the facility above the threshold quantity.  





ES 1.0 DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



PRIMARY OPERATIONS



The primary operation conducted at Kemira Water Solutions, Inc. Mojave facility is the manufacture of ferrous chloride and ferric chloride solutions (NAICS Code 32518, SIC Code 2819).  The primary components utilized in the process include water, hydrochloric acid, chlorine, and scrap iron.  Chlorine is a regulated substance subject to the above-referenced regulations, and is the only such regulated substance handled at the facility.  Provided below is a brief description of the storage, handling, and use of chlorine at the site.



STORAGE, HANDLING AND USE OF CHLORINE

ES 2.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SCENARIOS



 RMP regulations require the evaluation of at least two types of release scenarios for their potential to impact off-site populations:



- the worst-case release; and

- an alternative release (that is more credible or more likely).



In developing these release scenarios, a number of hypothetical accidental release scenarios were postulated and evaluated for the RMP.  These scenarios were categorized into worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios.  Each of these categories of hypothetical accidental release scenarios is discussed in the technical studies maintained at the facility.





ES 3.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the five years preceding the submittal of this RMP, the facility did not have a chlorine release incident that meets the five-year accident reporting criteria. The facility did not have a chlorine release incident that resulted in at least one of the following:

- Onsite injuries;

- Onsite deaths or significant property damage; or

- Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.



ES 4.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Accidental Release Prevention Program at Kemira Water Solutions, Inc. Mojave facility consists of a series of programs, procedures, and policies designed to minimize the risk of accidental releases involving chlorine.  These programs include design and operating controls, compliance with specified codes, the facility's health and safety program, numerous standard operating procedures, the equipment inspection and maintenance program (including a mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance program), site security, the management of change program, pre-startup safety review, fire prevention/fir

e protection/hot work permit program, management and safety of contractors, accident/incident investigation procedures, emergency response plan, RMP compliance auditing program, record keeping, and a variety of training programs.  Details of each of these components of the facility's Accidental Release Prevention Program are maintained at the facility.  



There are several chlorine leak detection and monitoring devices and other protective devices (e.g., for fire protection, etc.) placed at strategic locations throughout the facility.  In addition, the site has both manual and automatic shutoff systems to stop the flow of chlorine in an emergency.





ES 5.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE



Kemira Water Solutions, Inc. recognizes that emergency planning and emergency response are an integral component of risk management.   As such, the Mojave Plant currently has emergency action plans and emergency evacuation plans in place.  These programs work together to mitigate the effects of unplanned releases or events.  However, as a continuous measure to improve safety, the facility reviews its emergency response plan, evacuation plan, and fire prevention plan on a regular basis.  This review process also ensures that the facility incorporates the latest safety developments into its existing programs.





ES 6.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



A detailed hazard and operability study (i.e., hazards analysis) was performed on all operations involving chlorine in order to evaluate the potential for accidental releases in November 2016.  As required under the California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, section 2745.7 (q)(1-4) and 40 CFR 68, the hazards analysis included an analysis of natural and human-caused external events. As a result of the most recent 3-year compliance audit conducted in April and May 2018, improvements to our contractor management program, process safety information, work permit program, and document management system were identified

as part of the ongoing continuous improvement at the site. Additionally, in June 2017 the facility updated its seismic risk assessment.
